item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Pepperland

I've been leafing through The Dictionary of Imaginary Places by Alberto Manguel and Gianni Guadalupi.  It's a thick volume of 755 pages.  One of the entries intrigues me because it deals with The Beatles' folklore.  It reads:

"PEPPERLAND, a country eighteen thousand leagues beneath the Sea of Green, approached through the Sea of Holes.  Travellers will immediately notice that the keynote of Pepperland is colour; features of the landscape include hills of all colours, thick forests of painted trees where many-hued birds and butterflies abound, and rolling parkland.  The inhabitants dress in bright colours and rainbows are frequent.  There are no towns or cities in Pepperland, indeed few buildings of any sort; social life centres around the bandstand, for all Pepperlanders are players and lovers of music.

"Pepperland was originally colonized, four score and thirty-two bars ago, by Sgt. Pepper and his Lonely Hearts Club Band, who arrived in a yellow submarine (which can be seen today set on top of a pyramid).  The present ruler (called 'The Leader') is the Lord Mayor, a musician and conductor; he is assisted by Young Fred, a valiant Pepperlander.

"Petrified mountain spires along the borders surround Pepperland; here lived the Blue Meanies whose chief aim was to overcome Pepperland by turning it and its inhabitants blue and grey.  Led by their chief and his aide, Max, and using their principal weapon the Flying Glove, the Blue Meanies attacked the country.  Young Fred was dispatched in the yellow submarine to Liverpool, England, to persuade a group of four musicians, known with nostalgic affection as The Beatles, to return him to Pepperland.  The Blue Meanies, overcome by the Beatles' music, were driven off to Argentina, and Pepperland was restored to its colourful self."

It's intriguing to see political metaphors in Pepperland.  Can you see them?

blua:  blue.

dekstra:  right.

maldekstra:  left.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hey, It's fun to notice that there are some words in Esperando that resemble words in Portuguese... like "dekstra" in Portuguese is "destra". But the funny part is that "maldekstra" would mean in Portuguese "bad right", once "mal" means something bad or evil.

:P

Wow, I have that same book. I love reading through it on rainy evenings when the world seems boring and petty. It's fun to escape the confines of this world by imagining different places. It's even more fun to see how other people from different times and cultures created their own imaginary worlds too. Maybe some of them wrote about their imaginary worlds on rainy nights, when they also wanted to escape their boring and petty worlds.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Music Videos, Haiku, and Senryu

There's something about music videos that's a lot like haiku or senryu.  I've been watching the MuchMusic channel, which is the Canadian version of MTV.  Many music videos use brief thought-provoking imagery much like in haiku or senryu.  Concision is the key.

For those who have been away from earth, a haiku is a small unrhymed poem that usually deals with nature as linked with human nature and generally has three lines of 5-7-5 syllable pattern.  The senryu has the same pattern, but deals primarily with human nature, often humorously or satirically.  Used loosely, senryu means a poem that is similar to the haiku, but does not meet the criteria for haiku.  Music videos mainly deal with human nature, so they are more like senryu.

Hair is much too long--
and now then, buzz buzz clip clip
to feel short and cool.

longa:  long.

mallonga:  short.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Interesting perspective, and I LOVE your paradise pic.
i appreciate your analogy... i wish we could get muchmusic in the states on regular cable.... mtv sucks !!!

reading by twilight
words fall heavy on tired eyes
float gently within

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Fizz Fizz

I'm getting addicted to Dr. Pepper.  For the last three days, I have been drinking it.  For those who don't know, that's a cola drink with a slight pepper taste.  I've travelled quite a bit and I know that soft drinks around the world are as varied as the people.  In Japan, there is "Calpis Water," which is pronounced  "karupiss wotaa."  When I was there, I was addicted to it.  I have a red, white, and blue cola pop can with Arabic writing on it; I brought it from my Egyptian excursion.  I looked up the Arabic letters and they spell "Sahara."  I don't really remember how it tasted.  The can design looks like Pepsi.

Anyway, besides Dr. Pepper, I like root beer.  Yesterday, I was in a Chinese restaurant where I am a regular customer and I asked for root beer; the waitress came back with two brands of alcoholic beer, asking me to choose which one I wanted.  I said, "No, I want root beer, the soft drink."  It seemed as though she was frustrated at not being able to understand.  I then told another waitress that I wanted root beer; she knew it and came back with my drink.  The first waitress came back and said "Sorry."  I said, "That's okay.  Now you know where the root beer is."  I spelled it for her:  "R-O-O-T."  She gestured the spelling on the table and said "Thank you."  That's not the first time that a waitress in a Chinese restaurant has never heard of root beer.  Maybe, root beer is not popular in Hongkong.

trinki:  to drink.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm addicted to Dr.Pepper and Diet Dr.Pepper.

I have a friend in Virginia who claims Dr Pepper was named for a certain Doctor Pepper who lived in that state. I doubt that given that the drink was invented in Texas. When I was a kid there were rumors that its main ingredient was prune juice. That made it decidedly uncool for most of my friends. I didn't mind. I like prune juice.

Even for a red-meat-eater (very yang) soft-drinks are suicidal. Weak brittle bones, teeth, and flimsy nails. And not only hard things are meant to have high mineral content.

Look at your nails for moons. A healthy person has none. A well enough person has a moon on each thumb, and no more. The worse the constitution the more and the longer the growth of moons.

And light spots are events of toxic shock. Your nails are like a calender of the past. The date of manufacture keeps crawling out towards being clipped off.

Don't you hate it when you have a way to know how wrong you are!? Ignorance is BLISS!
To yogi: Well, I have no moons on my nails. I guess that I'm doing all right then. There was a time that I didn't drink pop, but ice tea. I always ordered ice tea. Well, I missed the taste of pop.
I'm relieved to note it is a moonless hand that now lifts an IBC Cream Soda to my lips.
I've been addicted to Dr. Pepper for a long, long time. But I have no moons on my nails.

I like that there are so many dumb things that we have in common with other countries. It seems to make America more down to earth, or the rest of the planet more worldly. I have a moon on seven of my fingers, but that is because I always get my nails done once in a while.

Ivy.
Ivy, I love that one. The ways of the Optimist are not for us Mortal others to know! Now that I changed my shirt I don't feel that bullet any more.

How about a survey. You people saying you have no moons; tell me the statistic in your age group, based on say a dozen or less cases. Sounds like "user-prognosis" to me, like the web virginity-statistic.

There was a rumor going around that Dr. Pepper was made with prunes.  Being that I like to examine urban legends, I thought this might interest you.

http://www.snopes.com/business/secret/drpepper.htm
i love dr pepper

My experiences in Chinese resturants is that the only sodas they sell are Coke or Sprite, no Root Beer. I also like Roob Beer with my food and have encountered this in many resturants, they just dont carry Roob Beer, only Coke and Pepsi.

Cherry Wind

I remember a couple of weeks ago a woman sweeping the cherry blossoms on the street and pavement.  It was virtually snowing petals from the trees.  The wind kept blowing the cherry blossoms to the ground, and still the woman kept sweeping.  I was astonished at how seemingly futile it was.  What made her do it?

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Predator

There was a big neighborhood yard sale yesterday.  I could have sold my old skis, but I didn't.  I went around the neighborhood and found an item that I liked and bought for 25 cents; it was a paperback book, German Stories, a bilingual text of short stories by famous German authors.  On the left side is German, the original, and on the right side is English.  Now I don't understand German myself.  I'm just curious.  It's just interesting to be engulfed by the "foreignness" of it.

I did find one other book in the yard sale that struck my fancy; it was an old 1960's science fiction paperback novel called Armageddon, complete with a beautiful, colorful 1960's cover.  It was an antique.  I think that it was one of the Buck Rogers' series.  It's too bad that I didn't buy it.  Actually, I left it there.  Then I came back later to find it again.  And it was gone.

tero:  earth.

luno:  moon.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: To Ninja:  "Luno" is Esperanto for the moon.  Here, "earth" represents the first book because now I actually have it; "moon" is the other book which I could not attain.
My latest garage sale purchase is a 1920 copy of Wuthering Heights written in French.  I do not read French well enough to read the book, but I couldn't pass it up.  It cost me fifty cents.
To eddievmail:  Lucky guy!  That's a good deal.

I wonder if the book you found but did not obtain was "Armageddon 2421" (or something like that)? I think there was a re-print in the '60s of the original by that name from the 1920s which was the first Buck (Tony in the book, the "Buck" came later in the movies) Rogers novel. I used to have a copy but it's gotten lost over the years. Perhaps that was it.
To rdolivaw:  Yeah, it was Armageddon 2421 (or some other year).  That was it.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Strawberry Reality

Reality is quite amazing.  Every morning I wake into it.  I still don't fully understand it, though.  It might be that I never will.  Is it a kind of dream?

But reality, although it may be full of unpleasantness, is also filled with pleasure.  I am reminded of this as I eat a whole box of large, juicy, red, fresh strawberries.

tago:  day.

nokto:  night.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: nicly done.  good thoughts.

I've thought that before. Is reality just a dream and our the dreams actually the reality? :)

scary stuff ;o

Olla, Victoro.

Got to thinking about Esperanto and remembered where I'd seen it actually used for a specific and official purpose.

When I was in Air Force basic training more years ago than I like to think about, we were tested on many subjects to determine our aptitudes. This would, of course, allow appropriate placement for either further training or direct assignment after boot camp. Part of the testing used Esperanto as a means of determining aptitude for languages (I recognized it as Esperanto as I had slogged my way through the Esperanto version of a magazine called "Science Digest" every month while I was in high school; most thought it was Spanish or Portugese). They used a self-training book to get through what was probably the first couple lessons in an Esperanto class, then tested us to see how much we'd retained. If you scored high enough, you could select language school as one of your "dream sheet" options for orders after basic. If you were selected for THAT, then you were trained/tested over a period of three days in Chinese (Mandarin), after which, if you passed, you listed three language choices. Most of us went to Chinese school in Monterey, CA and then to the Far East where we did what the "spy" plane that was recently forced down was doing when the incident occurred. Esperanto may, for all I know, still be part of the test -- it's a good choice because of the regularity of tenses, verb forms, etc., at least as a first cut.
To rdolivaw:  Saluton, samideano!  "Science Digest" in Esperanto?  I wonder if they still have that.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Temples

Well, it's a nice sunny day today.  I went to a big bookstore and sat there for a couple of hours reading.  I found one book, The New Buddhism: The Western Transformation of an Ancient Tradition by James W. Coleman, quite intriguing.  It describes the rapid growth of Buddhism in the West.  It was the "book of the day" for me.

In the bookstore, there's a whole big section on Eastern religions with very expensive, illustrated books.  It seems to indicate a huge, rich clientele.  Zen is chic.

I wouldn't say that I am particularly religious, but spiritual, yes.  I grew up in a Roman Catholic tradition.  My parents converted to Baptists when I was a teenager.  As for myself, I've been an eclectic for a number of years.  I've read about Hinduism, Buddhism, and other religions.  But I don't describe myself as belonging to any organized religion.  Well, I'm an explorer.  I have a path that zigzags the mountain slopes.  Essentially, I do believe there is an all-encompassing Intelligence in the universe.  But it essentially is Unknown.

I like going to places of worship if they look old and imposing.  On my various trips to Europe, I remember the beautiful Gothic and Baroque cathedrals; the box-like modern churches in my city pale in comparison.  There's an awesome spirit in those old churches that doesn't exist in the modern ones.  On my trips to Japan, I viewed the tranquil Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines.  In Thailand, I saw the towering golden Buddhist pagodas.  In Bali, Indonesia, I saw elaborate Hindu temples.  In Egypt, I saw exquisite mosques.  In Mexico, I saw ancient Mayan temples.  Near my parents' house here in Canada and near a golf course, there is a quaint Chinese Buddhist temple, complete with red-tiled roofing and ornamentation; it's an authentic-looking temple.  On rare moments, I would stroll there on a sunny day.

gotika:  gothic.

baroka:  baroque.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Sweet Potato

I spent several beautiful months living in Tokyo.  One of my fond memories was on one fine, crispy winter day in Ueno Park.  The sun was shining that day and the sky was clear and blue, although it was chilly.  There was a moving cart with an old man selling coal-baked sweet potato, or imo as the Japanese called it.  I bought one bulky piece.  I smothered the soft, steaming, orange flesh with melting butter.  I felt warm as I bit tenderly into it.  It was luscious.

The sweet potato is known scientifically as Ipomoea batatis.  I looked that up of course.  Lately, I've been developing an interest in knowing botanical names of plants.  But I've always had a love for biology even back in elementary and high school.  I sometimes regret that I didn't go on to study more of the subject in university, and instead went on to drier subjects like Computer Science.  I still love the organic.  Maybe I could have been a biochemist, genetic engineer, or some specialist in an exotic field of biology.  Well, there are many "could-haves" in one's life, but things turn out all right in the end.

vivo:  life.

vivi:  to live.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Somehow you make a sweet potato sound even more yummy. And I know what you mean about the biology. I can't get enough. Must be a Canadian thing seeing as how we still have so much of it left and untouched:-D

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Utopia

What is utopia?  The answer is different for everyone.  But for me, utopia is a place where beauty is almost everywhere.  Of course, for beauty to exist there must be ugliness, so one could note the contrast; otherwise, if everything is beautiful and there is no ugliness, one would think that beauty is mundane.  There is not much beauty in the mundane; that's almost like saying that the mundane is ugly.  But ugliness is there to remind people of beauty; one does not exist without the other.  The point is, in a utopia, there is much more beauty than ugliness.  It follows that, in a dystopia, there is much more ugliness than beauty.  Is reality a dystopia?  That probably depends on one's perspective.  If one reads the newspaper everyday and is engulfed in triflings and misery, one would probably tend to agree that reality is dystopic.

Yes, for me, utopia is mostly beauty with very small pockets of ugliness to define the contrast.  Beauty would encompass work and play; the city, the suburbs, and the countryside; people, plants, and animals; the sky, the land and the sea.

Beauty is a precursor to happiness and joy.  If beauty is almost everywhere, one would be happy almost all the time.  This is my belief.

belo:  beauty.

bela:  beautiful.

bele:  beautifully.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I wonder if beauty can be a state of mind as well?  I mean if one person finds beauty in a place and another does not is it in their perspective?  Wow....it's way to early here for this....:-D

Tracey

To Tracey:

Beauty can be a state of mind.  You're right.  It probably has something to do with mental health.  If a person finds ugliness in almost everything, there's probably a problem in his or her mind.

Anyway, thanks for visiting.  Cheers!

Ugliness is something beauty has not understood. When beauty understands ugliness it vanishes.

Parallel: Memory is something not perceived. When perception finds that time memory has its grip on the memory vanishes.

i love what you said about utopia being "mostly beauty with very small pockets of ugliness to define the contrast."

to me, it does apply to real life... reality is definitely not dystopia becos' having to experience all the pockets of bad things fate throws at me, it makes me realise much more how beautiful and joyful all the good things things in life can be, even the small things like breathing and smiling... :-)

Dankon, Viktoro, this entry of yours gave my spirit a much-needed lift.:-)
Ugliness is the fat me in the mirror. Beauifulness is see my Hubbies chest. Check out my weblogs new look.

If beauty can be a state of mind than the tired cliche, "Beauty is in the eye of the beholder" takes on a new meaning.  I'd like to think that perspective can be the difference in whether or not we see life as utopian or dystopia because if that is true than we have the power to live where we want.  Thanks for a great read!
Nicely written. I think beauty is everywhere. It just takes talented concentration to keep focused on it and appreaciate it......Paul

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Drinking Green

When I was in France touring, I remembered sitting in a quaint cafe near the entrance gates of the great Palace of Versailles one fine spring day.  I was thirsty.  I ordered creme de menthe from the waiter.  Then came a flask of water and a glass of clear, cool, green liquid.  One had to keep diluting the green liquid with water and drinking it gradually.  It was so soothing.  And I just couldn't be in a more romantic setting.  Ever since then, I have been daydreaming about creme de menthe.  It is now one of my favorite drinks.

mento:  mint.

akvo:  water.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: My story isn't nearly as exotic as yours, but it carries the same sentiment.  When I was going to college I worked at Disneyland.  On my days off I would often go to the park with the sole intention of listenning to the dixie land jazz bands in New Orleans Square while sipping a Mint Julep.  I would sit there for hours.  I often miss those warm summer evenings.
Thanks for visiting my weblogs. It's interesting to read yours. It makes me thirsty :-)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Mother's Wrath

Mother's Day is coming up.  I don't like these days when I have to buy presents.  It's just an economic trick to increase the GNP.  I'm not much of a consumer.  Well, I just bought her a nice, stylish, wooden picture frame.  That should be all right.

Of course, I do love my mother.  We get along fine most of the time.  She always cooks and bakes delicious food for me.  But sometimes she is in a bad mood.  One could tell by the nasty words she sometimes uses, like last night on the phone.  Whenever that happens, I do get irritated and I forget that I do love her.  That is too bad that she's so moody.  She's probably under stress or something.

amo:  love.

ami:  to love.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
My Own Language

I've always wanted to create my own language.  This was even before I'd heard about Esperanto, the most famous one of artificial languages.  Even as a child, I had a tendency to create my own words, like brabintai for 'dragonfly' and mooninghai for 'moon'.  Moreover, my lifelong study of different natural languages had given me an insight into and appreciation for the structure of language in general.

I like the simple phonological systems of languages like Spanish, Japanese, and Swahili.  If I were to create my own language, it would only have the simple A, E, I, O, and U sounds ("ah," "eh," "ee," "oh," "oo")  for vowel sounds, not the various gray shades of ambigious vowel sounds inherent in English or French.  It should be simple. 

Spelling should be perfectly regular.  Spelling Bee contests are just so ridiculous.  There are just hundreds, maybe thousands, of hours spent memorizing strings of letters when one is growing up with a language like English.  There should be a one-to-one correspondence between what's written and what's spoken.  Most likely, I would use the Roman alphabet.

Above all, the grammar should be simple.  I've been intrigued by the grammar of Japanese; although it is markedly different, it seems simpler in some ways than Spanish or French, which has complex verb conjugations.  Verbs should be simple.  English gets high marks for verb simplicity, though.  Note the following conjugations for the verb 'to speak' for different persons in the present tense:

English:  I, you, we, they speak.  He, she, it speaks.

Spanish:  hablo, hablas, habla, hablamos, hablan.

French:  parle, parles, parle, parlons, parlez, parlent.

Japanese:  hanashimasu (for all).

Esperanto:  parolas (for all).

Creating my own language sounds like a fun project.  However, whenever I want to document my imaginary language, I always change my mind on something or other.  My tastes change.  It's like a moving target.  It cannot be perfect, naturally.

But Esperanto is there.  It's an amazing fact that it is artificial, yet elegant, simple, and expressive at the same time.  Esperanto is already a living language with hundreds of thousands of speakers, even though it is an invented language.  It seems that I cannot outdo the work of Dr. L. L. Zamenhof, the creator of Esperanto.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Good entry! It's great to read about another linguophile's thoughts. My comments: I prefer to leave things as they are. The languages of the world have so much unique flavour & rich history, brought out in part by their phonology, scripts etc. Esperanto to me is rather eurocentric. Replacing languages with any universal language will unavoidably cause great discontinuity in many cultures. Esperanto may have great value as an auxiliary language for international communication, but not, I think, as a 'mother tongue' for all nations.

What a wonderful post.  I too love language, but a little differently, I think.  I love how words are sort of like a butterfly net, they toss themselves out into the air and scoop up some meaning.  Sometimes a little of the meaning escapes, sometimes you get something you didn't expect, and there is always more to catch.  I really look forward to coming back and checking out your thoughts.  (good luck on mothers day)!

Usually artifically developed anythings are less likely to be accepted than that which develops organically. Esperanto was probably the most successful attempt (I used to read the Esperanto version of Science Digest when I was in high school in the '60s). However, various languages have become the lingua franca for a time, then passed by in favor of another. English has that dubious honor at present, having replaced French some time ago, which itself had replaced Latin. What's next? Japanese? Chinese? The latter might be a good selection: it's much less inflected than even English. The difficulty there, though, is that the written version is extremely difficult and a "Romanized" version is not likely to make it any better due to the very limited number of phonemes available (217) and the monosylabic nature of the language. One sound can stand for many different meanings, differentiated somewhat by vocal "tone," but really only definable by context.
Very interesting. I would like to see a language that almost sounds musical when spoken.

Serious communication ends its own past; serious language is always new. All natural sounds that seem to repeat actually never repeat. Record any natural creatures expression and analyse its parts in full, and it proves unique. The similarity is just a parallel to the similarity of form. A dove, for example, always looks like a dove, and so it always sounds like a dove. In its physical expression it changes subtly, and in its vocal as well. Even re: human natural language, laughter, people always say, "You laughed! What is funny?" as if laughter always said one thing; and never explained anything.

Conscious is a way to explain what was already explained, but this time so it makes no sense.

I can read (in this case, I only mean decipher the pronunciation of) a few scripts: Roman, Greek, Cyrillic, Urdu (related to Persian & Arabic) and Chinese. I think the complexity of Chinese script alone makes Chinese unlikely to become a global lingua franca. It's not an alphabetic script, and the characters themselves can be quite complicated. We even learn the order in which to write the pen-strokes!

rdolivaw is right, a purely romanised version will be quite difficult to read. Korean script is quite novel, each character has a simple left-right-bottom structure to indicate the sound of onset, vowel and coda. But when there might be uncertainty as to what word it is, they write the original Chinese word; which means that they study 2 writing systems for the one language!

As for a musical language, Cantonese seems a good candidate.

Dutch: ik praat, jij praat, hij praat, wij praten, zij praten, jullie praten

Malou   =)
To Phoebe:  Thanks for the Dutch translations.

http://members.aol.com/amisource/hearflash.htm

muziko:  music.

muzika:  musical.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I've been to Egypt and Jordan as a tourist and I couldn't agree with you more - thanks for the link! :-)

Tracey
I've that they are beautiful places.

I've been to Israel as a tourist and I fell in love with the people, their culture and the land.  There is something sublime about walking on streets that are older than any building street bridge or wall in the States.  I constantly thought about who came before and how I was, even just for those few weeks, a part of that place.
There is something so magical about the world's music. Thank you.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Rebellious Graffiti

In North America and Europe, graffiti are everywhere.  Public buildings, walls, buses, and trains do not escape them.  Many believe that they are unsightly and unwelcome scribblings by rebellious punks.  But on close scrutiny, graffiti are actually art.  Like Oriental calligraphy, they exemplify a free spirit as displayed by the masterful strokes and curves used.

When I lived in Tokyo for a year, I didn't see any graffiti.  Probably, since calligraphy is an established artform there, graffiti become redundant.  A niche is already filled.  The spirit of graffiti and the spirit of Oriental calligraphy are a little different as the former embodies rebellion and the latter embodies tranquillity.

I think that Eastern writing systems, like Japanese, Chinese, and Arabic, have a smooth, free, organic flow about them that satiates the emotional mind, but Roman letters are rigid and stern; only in graffiti are they released rebelliously from this rigidity.

skribi:  to write.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Do you think, perhaps, that the lack of graffiti might also be partially due to a cultural difference? From what I understand - and I am by no means an expert on Japanese culture - their society is, in general, more respectful than ours.

Graffiti is not just art, it's also the destruction of property.
To espoir: Yes, the Japanese being more respectful may have something to do with the lack of grafitti. And, yes, grafitti are vandalism too of course.
You should swing by Singapore sometime. You hardly see any graffiti here. Thank goodness - graffiti is an eyesore.
To isisflower:  I was in Singapore for three days and I didn't see any grafitti.  By the way, the food there is fabulous.
You can see graffiti as art in Sakuragichou, Yokohama.
There is graffiti in Singapore. Look in the back seats of buses and in some toilets. But it's banal, scrawly stuff. Artistic graffiti is great-- as long as you do it on your own property! ;-)

Oops!  I misspelt 'graffiti' as 'grafitti'.  I edited the text.  Thanks for everyone for letting me know the right spelling.  That should be 'graffiti'.  Well, 'spaghetti' misled me with its two T's.  Excuses.

item.dc:creator: viktoro

Persone:  Esperanto Rocks

I've heard that tofu cheesecake is better for your body than real cheesecake.  Tofu burgers are healthier than real burgers.  Is rock music better with an artificial ingredient?  An artificial language, that is.  Well, there's a Swedish band that sings in Esperanto.  The band is Persone, pronounced 'pehrr-SOH-neh'; it means 'personally'.  Persono means 'person'; persona means 'personal'; persone means 'personally'.  It's logical, isn't it?

I'll let you be the judge as to whether their music is up to your high-class standards.  If you ask me, I think they're fairly good.  Here's the website with sound samples:

http://www.concinnity.se/bertilow/persone/sono.htm

I write songs and I think I'll try writing in an artificial tongue.  Depending on how it comes out I may post it.  Also, thanks for checking out my site today.  L8 E~

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Tokyo Pop

I have several pop music CDs that I bought when I lived in Japan a while back.  From the dusty shelf, I took out the albums Roi Roi by GAO and So Bad by T-Bolan.  Feeling nostalgic, I played them while I read the lyrics.  It's amazing how much Japanese I have retained.  I still know a few kanji logographs, while the katakana and hiragana phonetics seem like old friends to me.  But I still don't understand everything, of course.  I wish that I did.

The Japanese rock music reminds me of the serendipitous times that I had while I lived in the giant, vibrant labyrinth of Tokyo.  I used to walk long walks in my favorite districts:  Harajuku, Shinjuku, and Ueno.  I used to haunt the green parks, ancient temples, and crowded bookstores.  I loved it.  I fell in love with Tokyo.  I wish that I could have stayed longer; I stayed one beautiful year.  Living there was virtually my second childhood; everything that I discovered was new and exciting.

nova:  new.

malnova:  old.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
To phildynan:  Tokyo is a very complex city.  Each district has a special character.  It would take a lifetime to explore.  One district, Akihabara, is full of the latest amazing electronic gadgets, some of which would never be seen in markets outside Japan.  Another district, Shinjuku, is Las Vegas on steroids, a cornucopia of blaring neon lights and night life.  Harajuku is where the young hip people hang out, dancing on the streets during weekends.  Roppongi is where the discos and bars are; 'gaijins', or foreigners, haunt this area.  Ueno is a place of a huge, relaxing, green park with old museums; also there are shops for cheap merchandise.  Asakusa is a site of an old temple.  Ginza is a place for expensive upper-class boutiques.  There's another district where one could find all sorts of realistic plastic food, from fake sushi to fake ice cream sundaes.  Yet another district is a haven for antique shoppers:  a place where one could find interesting pre-war curiosities, like old abacuses, calligraphic scrolls, fertility symbols, statuettes, and so forth.  Besides the very visual aspect of the city, one could always smell some tantalizing, delicious food in the air, like baked sweet potato or skewered octopus balls.

Just outside Tokyo are quaint towns where old native architecture can still be seen.  I often took the train going to the quiet outskirts of the megalopolis, not really knowing where I would end up.  I would find myself in the most curious places.

I'm glad that you like Tokyo that way. And also, your description is beautiful!!

Thank you for the thoughtful comment on my page.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Esperanto

Here's a good question...

bartonz:  Are there very many people who actually speak Esperanto? It seems like I only see it written.

I belong to a local club in which we practice speaking Esperanto.  I've met people from all over the world who speak it in varying degrees; they're from  Italy, Britain, Malta, Bulgaria, Germany, South Korea, Canada, and so forth.  Esperanto mainly appeals to peace-loving dreamers and utopists.  Nobody knows for sure as it depends on the degree of fluency, but there are estimates of 100,000 to 8 million speakers of Esperanto, although the most likely estimate is 2 million.

Here's a fun, animated mini-course on Esperanto:  http://www.esperanto.ca/kurso/

revi:  to dream.

revo:  a dream.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have studied many languages briefly, and never could decide which I wanted to really know well.  This could be a good idea!

You've taught me my quota for languages aujourd'hui.  I'm multilingual; French, Spanish, English (hahaha, some days) and learning German, maybe...  I had no idea there was such a language --  There are some serious similarities to Spanish, and hey, to French, for that matter...
Thanks for the fun website link.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
I've been reading Creating Affluence by Deepak Chopra.  I have a quote:

A billion dollars in the bank, without the experience of carefreeness and charity, is a state of poverty.  Wealth consciousness, by definition, is a state of mind.  If you are constantly concerned about how much money you need, then irrespective of the actual dollar amount you have in your account, you are really poor.  (page 29)

Thinking about billions of dollars, if I were as rich as Bill Gates, I would probably erect a castle in the state of Washington, somewhere in the mountains and forest.  It would be like those grand castles in Europe that we see on postcards, complete with fancy turrets and moats.  Yeah, fantasy's great!  What would you do with billions of dollars?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Not much, I think the shock might kill me! Actually, I have the same kind of fantasy as you do. I have always loved medieval castles, and I am inclined to want to live in the mountains and be reclusive, just writing and dreaming... I would love a life like that  :-)

http://www.xanga.com/home.asp?user=wyvickyng

hey, thanks for your comment, ha ha, yeah, my mami do cooked very well! ^_^

hm...you seemed read many many books! Medieval castles...I think it's somewhat terrifying...

For me, i prefer having a simple house in grassland, with some sheep and cows, a swing hang on the tree, the most important-living with my family...hey! the kind of house like Forest Gump's is my ideal dreamhouse for me...

"If I were a rich man,

deedle diedle, diedle, deedle, deedle, diedle, deedle, dee;

all day long I'd deedle diedle dee, if I were a wealthy man!"

I would make life easier for as many people around me as I could. You're right, money doesn't buy happiness. It does however, give the power to do good. The Bible says, whenever it is within your power to give, you must.

Hmm…. A billion dollars…. I think that I’ll use it to realize this childhood dream of mine to build a farmhouse in the rurals where I’ll rear every type of animal in this world in my courtyard, plant every type of plant in the garden and live there for the rest of my life with my family and loved ones tending to all the necessary chores each day and living harmoniously with nature…. It sounds too idealistic and childish huh? :-P But, it’s just a dream of mine and well, it never hurts to dream right? ;-)

idan:  You should really come to Israel and visit Jerusalem. So old but so well preserved. Amazing and so very fascinating history. So much to see. It's a wonder!

Me:  Well, I've only been to Hongkong.  I guess that counts as "China" now.  If you would like to "taste" the language, you might try Mandarin, the bigger cousin of Cantonese.  Mandarin has only four tones, compared to the six in Cantonese; thus, Mandarin might be easier in that respect.  For me, living in North America and there being so many Cantonese migrants here, Cantonese seems a natural target.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I wanna go!

First off, thank you for your props and appreciation to the picture I put on my web log.

You are an interesting person! Learning many languages is good for one, especially Chinese languages. Absolutely, mandarin is easier to master. I am a Chinese and I am still learning Cantonese. :-)  If you are travelling to China and Taiwan, mandarin would be more useful than Cantonese. However if you travel to Hong Kong, the right language is Cantonese. Again if you know how to speak mandarin, you can travel to all these countries in Asia (Taiwan, China and Hong Kong). 

Keep up your interest!  :-) {v}

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Likable Cities And Cultural Immersion

Some cities to which I've been and which really fascinate me are:  Paris, France; Vienna, Austria; Tokyo, Japan; Kyoto, Japan; Salamanca, Spain; and Luxor, Egypt.  Places with very old buildings intrigue me.  I could just feel the history surrounding me.  It's a great feeling!

If someone were to ask me where I would most want to live, right now, that would be Paris...  But my taste changes with time, so next time it could be a different place.  But Paris I like because of its grand architecture, wide boulevards, quaint streets, and refined culture.  I wish that I were fluent in French so that I could just blend in with the crowds there.  But probably even if I were fluent, I would still stand out.  The Parisians are snappy dressers.  I dress for comfort.  People would know.  It doesn't matter; I'm not a conformist.

I decided that I don't have to be in a particular place to enjoy a different culture.  Now, I immerse myself in the French language by reading books, listening to French-language radio, and watching French-language television, TV5.  TV5 is a great channel, which one could receive by cable or satellite.  It's an international Francophone channel with news and entertainment mostly from Europe:  France, Switzerland, and Belgium.  I can't quite catch everything said on TV5, but I'm getting used to parsing the words.  TV5 has a web site at http://www.tv5.org .

Actually, in the Canadian city where I live now, a useful second language would be Cantonese.  There are just multitudes of Cantonese in the city.  I could hear their singsong language everyday.  Their culture is very apparent in the city.  Quite often, I would eat out in a local Chinese restaurant.  The prices are very good and the food is just fabulous.

I took an eight-week course in Cantonese just for fun a while back.  But I really don't remember too much.  The tones are really difficult to grasp.  I find Japanese words easier to remember than Cantonese words.  I can't really be too sure of the pronunciation of Cantonese because the sounds are really "foreign."  Well I just wanted to "taste" what Cantonese is like.  It's not a language that I could possibly master even if I wanted to.  I should stick with French.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You should really come to israel and visit Jerusalem. So old but so well preserved. Amazing and so very fascinating history. So much to see. It's a wonder!

I think it's so fantastic that you took a course in Cantonese!  I've travelled a lot too and love visiting new places and finding new cultures - I've never been to China but I'd love to try and learn the language...mind you...I find Japanese hard enough for the little I know....:-)

Tracey
Do you live in Québec?
To barefeetallowed:  I live on the West Coast.
i entirely relate to the bit about feeling the history in old buildings; one of the reasons i want to travel so badly...  i envy you your mobility :-)

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Dolce Far Niente

One of my favorite phrases is Italian:  "Dolce far niente" (Sweet to do nothing).  It's the 'pleasant idling' that a select few people seem to grasp or enjoy.  It's when one sips a cool glass of creme de menthe at a café, watching people stroll by.  It's when one naps on a hammock in the sunny yard of a country house.  It's when one is just "hanging out" or doing nothing in particular.  That's right:  hanging out is "dolce far niente."  In an increasingly busy world, "doing nothing" seems like a crime or a luxury.  To me, it's the essence of simply "being."  After all, we're "human beings," not "human doings."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I only wish everyone had more time to just do nothing, and enjoy what happens around them.

~Kelly~

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Tropics

I used to live in the tropics.  Our house sat a few meters from a cliff.  Behind the house was a veranda with a brick barbecue stall.  From the veranda, one could see over the cliff:  mountains and fields of long grass.  There were few houses in the neighborhood and they were scattered far and wide.  In that vicinity, the soil was rusty red and the wild grasses grew tall, yellowed by the heat of the sun.  Big dust devils would whirl about the fields.  Peanuts grew well in the area, but the watermelon didn't grow too big.  When the typhoons came, the water poured down so strongly that it carved the red soil.  It was a great place to grow up.

Now I'm no longer in the tropics, but in a colder, temperate land.  The winters are bitter cold for me.  But at least the summers are warm and dry, not hot and humid like in the tropics.  But I still miss the tropics from time to time.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
I've been fantasizing about writing a fiction novel, maybe science fiction or fantasy.  I've read more science fiction books than fantasy; therefore, I'm more aware of the elements of a science fiction book, but fantasy intrigues me because of its timeless, more classical attributes.

I haven't really started on it yet.  I'm still thinking of what to write.  I'm still not sure of the mechanics.  And I'm hesitating to sit for hours writing in front of the screen.  It wouldn't be a trivial pursuit; that's for sure.  Also, I hope my old 166 MHz computer with 64 MB of RAM can handle it.  A novel can sit in one huge Word file; it could be really slow, but I haven't tried a big file.

I'm not sure if I'll write it for adults or for juveniles (age 9 - 12).  Writing for juveniles might be more difficult because I'll have to think like a child.  But I've read that juvenile fiction is a lucrative market.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The juvenile market can be a lucrative one if, you can break into it.  I found it hard enough to break into the young adult market and I was 15 at the time (when I signed the first contarct)...  It's worth it if you have the heart to persevere.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
I have a lot of time on my hands, so I'm learning French.  I started my studies around late spring of 2000.  I took French in high school and first-year college and I still remember a lot of it.  Recently, I bought about 20 science fiction novels in French at 50 cents each from a book sale at the library.  I plodded along one novel so far.  I needed my dictionary all the time to look up words.  I didn't understand everything that went on in the book.  But I sensed that there was progress.  Almost everyday I listen to a French-language radio station so that I can parse the words.  I'm learning.  And it's a great feeling to sense that one's learning.

I took serious study of Japanese some years back, but did not progress as much as I wanted.  Although the grammar of Japanese is quite easy, retaining a vocabulary so different from English was very difficult.  At least with French, there are so many words that are cognate with English; if you know English words, you already know many French words.  Also, Japanese writing is a great barrier.  I know all the syllabaries for writing phonetics; those are relatively simple, but what's complicated are the "kanji," the logographs.  There's just so much memorization involved.  I realized that learning French would show more progress for me.

I started learning Esperanto back in 1997.  I got hooked.  It's so easy to learn.  Esperanto is an invented language and it's highly regular.  I was so enthused that I joined an Esperanto club and learned to speak it.  I like the philosophy behind the language:  "an easy second language for all."  It's as if I joined a revolution or something.  But still, Esperanto seems to belong in the realm of fantasy and of dreamers.  So having learned it seems surreal.  I wish that more people knew about it.  I wish Esperanto all the success that it deserves.  However, I keep up with my French no matter how difficult it is because it's something more real.  French is real; Esperanto is surreal.  I like them both.  I like Japanese too, but for the reasons that I mentioned, functional literacy in it is relatively beyond my reach.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I know learning Japanese is difficult for westerners. But, if you ask me, you are lucky to be born as a native English speaker, because you can learn other western languages easily.
Sou desu ne.  But you are lucky because you know so much kanji.  There's just so much aesthetic value to those symbols.

We have a Japanese student staying with us until the end of June - She may be returning for next year's school year...  If you need any help at all with French, let me know.  I took 12 years of Immersion, and 3 years of Francophone French before moving into an English (high) school for the second time in my life (after junior kindergarten)... I love the language and all the power to you if you can get a good grasp on both the oral and written elements...

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded: I love coconut.  It's best when it's still green on the outside and the succulent, white flesh is tender inside.  The juice is sweet and has that distinctive flavour which only a coconut has.  Ah!  Yummy!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded: I imagine a city as glorious as Paris.  It's name is Sankta Lorenzo.  It's crisscrossed by wide, broad boulevards, profusely lined with shrubs and trees.  The architecture is old and resplendent from colonial days of European settlers.  But the city is dotted with the slender pagodas of Buddhist temples.  Half the inhabitants are Roman Catholics and half are Buddhists.  One encounters also the extravagance of baroque churches.  The city is a tranquil blend of the East and West, as are its people:  the indigenous population and descendents of Europeans.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
The previous entry entitled "Lingvoj en Filipinoj" is an article that I wrote for the Canadian Esperanto Association (Kanada Esperanto-Asocio).  It's in Esperanto.  Can you read some of it?  Maybe you can still figure some of it out even if it's in a different language.

By the way, the letter 'j' in Esperanto sounds like the English 'y' as in 'yoyo'.  In German, 'j' is like 'y' too.  Ja!

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Lingvoj en Filipinoj

Pli ol 7100 vulkanaj insuloj sin banas jen en paca tropika suno, jen en perfortaj tajfunoj. Tio estas Filipinoj, lando de kontrastoj kaj paradoksoj, kunfandigho de la Okcidento kaj Oriento. Pri kio oni pensas kiam iu mencias la vorton 'Filipinoj'? Eble oni memoras la tromulton da shuoj de Imelda Marcos au la revoluciojn kontrau koruptaj prezidentoj. Sed kompreneble Filipinoj estas pli ol nur tio. Filipinoj estas lando de diverseco kaj en popolo kaj lingvo.

Etnologia studo ( http://www.sil.org/ethnologue ) listigas 168 vivantajn lingvojn parolatajn en Filipinoj. Ili estas ja tre diversaj. Pliparto da tiuj lingvoj apartenas al la Austronezia (Malajo-Polinezia) lingvofamilio, al kiu ankau la Havaja, Fighia, Samoa, kaj Indonezia lingvoj apartenas. El la indighenaj lingvoj de Filipinoj, ok chefaj lingvoj havas pli ol unu milionon da parolantoj. Tiuj kaj iliaj unualingvaj loghantaraj procentoj estas [1] la Tagaloga (29,3%), en Manilo, centra kaj suda Luzon, kaj en la insuloj de Mindoro kaj Marinduque; [2] la Cebua (23,3%), en Cebu, Bohol, orienta Negros, okcidenta Leyte, kaj partoj de Mindanao; [3] la Iloka (9.3%), en nordaj partoj de Luzon; [4] la Hiligajnona (9,1%), en partoj de Panay kaj okcidenta Negros; [5] la Bikola (5,7%), en suda Luzon kaj Catanduanes; [6] la Varaj-Varaja (3,8%), en Samar kaj Leyte; [7] la Pampanga (3,0%), en partoj de centra Luzon; kaj [8] la Pangasina (1,8%), en centra Luzon. La Filipina loghantaro estas nun pli ol 73 milionoj.

La nacia, kaj plej parolata, lingvo de Filipinoj estas la Filipina, kiu bazighas sur la Tagaloga. Praktike la Tagaloga kaj la Filipina estas sinonimaj, sed teorie la Filipina estas plilarghigo de la Tagaloga. La Tagaloga estas la plej richa de chiuj Filipinaj lingvoj kaj havas la plej vastan literaturon. La Tagalogan parolas multaj Filipinanoj kiel duan lingvon. La lingvo estas instruata en lernejoj en tutaj Filipinoj.

La diversaj indighenaj lingvoj ofte estas tiom malsamaj kiel oni ne interkomprenighas, sed multaj vortoj estas similaj. Ekzemple, 'Multajn dankojn' estas, en la Tagaloga, 'Maraming salamat' kaj estas, en la Cebua, 'Daghang salamat'. 'Mia lando estas Filipinoj' estas Tagaloge 'Aking bayan ang Pilipinas' kaj estas Cebue 'Akong nasud ang Pilipinas'. Feliche por interkomprenighi inter aliaj etnoj, multaj Cebuanoj parolas ankau la Tagalogan. La Tagaloga, la lingvo de la plej potenca etno (la Tagalogoj), estas la tut-Filipina komunikilo.

La Tagaloga havas 20 literojn: A, B, K, D, E , G, H, I, L, M, N, Ng, O, P, R, S, T, U, W, Y. Ghi havas simplan sonsistemon kaj havas fonetikan ortografion. La Tagaloga gramatiko tamen estas morfologie pli malsimpla ol la Indonezia, ghia kuza lingvo. La verbo shanghighas al multaj formoj, depende de la tempo kaj la fokuso.

La historio de la Filipina kiel la nacia lingvo ampleksas pli ol 60 jarojn. La Nacia Lingva Instituto establighis la 13an de novembro 1936 sekve al la 'Commonwealth Act Number 184' por la studado de la Filipinaj dialektoj por evoluigi kaj adopti komunan nacian lingvon bazitan sur unu el ekzistantaj indighenaj lingvoj. Tio necesigis la studadon de chiuj indighenaj lingvoj parolitaj de pli ol duonmiliono da Filipinanoj kaj la elekton de lingvo kiel la bazo de la nacia lingvo. En 1937 la Instituto rekomendis la Tagalogan kaj eldonis gramatikon kaj vortaron. En 1959 la Departemento de Eduko nomighas la Tagalog-bazita lingvo 'Pilipino' kaj ekdisvastigis ghin. Estis multaj novaj vortoj kreitaj el malnovaj radikoj. La Konstitucio de 1973 do deklaris, ke la Nacia Asembleo devus evoluigi kaj adopti komunan nacian lingvon nomitan 'Filipino', supozeble bazitan je Pilipino. Dume Pilipino kaj la Angla restis kiel oficialaj lingvoj. En la 1970aj jaroj, Pilipino enkondukighis kiel la lingvo de edukado kune kun la Angla.

La Konstitucio de 1987 deklaris, ke la nacia lingvo de Filipinoj estas Filipino, evoluanta kaj richigata je la bazo de ekzistantaj Filipinaj kaj aliaj lingvoj. Kiel Filipino kaj Pilipino malsamas? Filipino [1] havas pli da fonemoj au literoj; [2] havas malsaman sistemon de ortografio; [3] havas pli da pruntvortoj el la Angla; [4] havas malsaman gramatikon. La aktuala Manila Tagaloga estas la bazo de Filipino. Estas oportune, ke en Esperanto oni povus uzi la vorton 'Filipina' kiel sinonima ghenerala vorto al la Tagaloga, Pilipino, kaj Filipino. La malsameco de tiuj montras politikan tendencon.

Filipinojn koloniis dufoje Okcidentanoj. Filipinojn koloniis la Hispanoj dum 333 jaroj ekde la 16a jarcento. Post la Hispana-Usona Milito kaj ekde 1898 Usono administris Filipinojn. En 1946 Filipinoj gajnis sendependecon. Pro tiu kialo la aktuala paroladon de Filipinanoj havas multajn pruntvortojn el la Hispana kaj la Angla.

La tipa Tagaloga frazo 'Ang aking kotse ay asul' signifas 'Mia automobilo estas blua'; 'kotse' estas el la Hispana 'coche' (automobilo) kaj 'asul' estas el la Hispana 'azul' (blua). Se Filipinojn koloniis la Hispanoj dum 333 jaroj, kial Filipinanoj ne parolas la Hispanan? Fakte nuntempe malmultaj Filipinanoj parolas flue la Hispanan. Malsame kiel en Meksiko, la Hispanaj monahhoj ghenerale ne instruis sian lingvon al la indighenoj por ke ili pli bone regu ilin, kaj malpermesis aliron al gravaj instuticioj kiel la Eklezio. Ankau malsame kiel en Meksiko, malmultaj Hispanoj vivis efektive en Filipinoj. Ankau kiam la Usonanoj alvenis, la novaj koloniistoj promociis aktive la Anglan al la indighenoj. Sed fakte estas Hispanbazita kreolajho, la Chavakana, kiun parolas chirkau trionmiliono da Filipinanoj.

Kiam alvenis la Hispanoj, ili enkondukis la Roman alfabeton al la indighenoj. Nuntempe chiuj chefaj Filipinaj lingvoj skribighas per la Romaj literoj. Antaue estis antikva indighena skribsistemo, kiu nomighas 'Baybayin'. En 1604 Jezuita historiisto, Pedro Chirino, skribis en dokumento Relacion de las Islas filipinas, ke inter la insulanoj skribado kaj legado estis popularaj je Baybayin. Baybayin ampleksas seriojn da silaboj; efektive ghi ne estas alfabeto, sed silabaro. Ekzemple, simbolo, kiu aspektas kiel inversa koro sonas kiel ba; kiam estas punkto super tiu, ghi sonas kiel bi; kiam estas punkto sub tiu, ghi sonas kiel bu. Antaue la Tagaloga estis esence trivokala.

Tio estis la pasinteco de la Tagaloga. Pri la estonteco, kio estos? Nuntempe la influo de la Angla regas. En Manilo oni audas familiaran lingvon, kiun oni nomas 'Tagangla' (Taglish). Ghi estas kunfandigho de la Tagaloga kaj la Angla. Multaj sentas, ke la Tagangla estas lingvacho. Ekzemplo de tio estas: 'By the way, may klase ako bukas. In fact, busy ako buong araw. Puwede bang magkita tayo next week?' (Parenteze, mi havos klason morgau. Fakte, mi estos okupata la tutan tagon. Chu ni povas kunveni la venontan semajnon?) En amaskomunikiloj oni audas kaj legas la Taganglan. Malgrau la registaraj politikoj pri lingva uzo de Pilipino au Filipino, la Tagangla regas.

Tajlandanoj rigardas Holivudajn filmojn kun Taja subteksto. Indonezianoj rigardas Holivudajn filmojn kun Indonezia subteksto. Sed Filipinanoj rigardas Holivudajn filmojn sen subteksto rekte en sia lingvo. Fakte, pri la Angla mem, 52% da Filipinanoj konstatas, ke ili scipovas ghin. Sed tiu procento vershajne reduktighos en la estonteco! Pli kaj pli da la Tagaloga, la Filipina, enkondukighas en chiuj niveloj de la lernejoj. Eble estonte malpli da Filipinanoj estos fluaj parolantoj de la Angla. En sia sercho por nacia identeco, la Filipinanoj sentas, ke la Filipina pli gravas al ili. Kaj estas dilemoj. La Angla estos ankorau grava kiel interkomunikilo kun la ekstera mondo. Ankau la Manilocentra Tagalogcentra lingva politiko sentigas kelkajn ne-Tagalogojn kiel speco de nova koloniismo, pro kiu aliaj Filipinaj lingvoj pashon post pasho elpushighos. Tamen, multaj Filipinanoj, inkluzive de ne-Tagalogoj, sentas, ke ili vere bezonas nacian lingvon.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Sabi and Wabi

I read a book recently called The Japanese Have a Word for It.  There were two interesting words which I re-discovered and which I encountered before:  "sabi" and "wabi."  "Sabi" means the venerable antique look of an object like the rust on old pipes or the moss growing on an old tree.  "Wabi" is the quiet refinement or tranquility of an object.  Both sabi and wabi are important elements in Japanese aesthetics.  They're difficult to translate into English.  Their adjectival forms "sabishii" and "wabishii" mean desolate or lonely, but not entirely in the negative sense that a Westerner might think.  It's desolate and lonely in an artistic sense.  Is it twisted?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Very deep! :-)  I love finding out things like this - especially since I live in Japan myself - thanks!

Tracey

I agree with Tracey. Very deep!

The spirit of "wabi" and "sabi" is difficult
even for Japanese people to understand.
I think that many Japanese youngsters don't know even the words, "wabi"and "sabi."

Thanks for subscribing.
I lived and worked in Japan for a year.  I just loved it there!  There was such an artistic spirit among the people.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Esperanto for You!

Is Esperanto for you?

Did you ever wish that spelling could be easy and words would be spelt the way they sound? Then Esperanto is for you. Spelling in Esperanto is effortless.

Did you ever want to learn a really easy language and admire it for its simplicity? Did you ever want to learn a language like French, Spanish, or Italian, but found it too difficult? Then Esperanto is for you. Esperanto is a very simple language.

Do you like the idea of an invented, planned language? And the whole idea of an invented language excites you? Then Esperanto is for you. Esperanto is an invented language. In fact, it is one of the most incredible, though lesser known, inventions of modern times.

Would you learn a language just as a work of art? Then Esperanto is for you. Esperanto is an artist's creation.

First publicized in 1887 by Dr. L. L. Zamenhof, Esperanto is a language designed to ease communication between people of different cultures.

To put it in historical perspective, the Eiffel Tower was built for the 1889 Paris Exposition by Gustave Eiffel.  Both the Eiffel Tower and Esperanto remain architectural marvels today.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded: My niece, Tria, who's almost three years old, likes orange.  A few days ago after she woke up from a nap, I asked her what she dreamt.  She said there was a bird.  I asked her what color the bird was.  She said at first that it was red, then she said it was orange.  That's why I chose the orange background for this site.
